hints_html:
In the power iteration procedure, the convergent vector \(\displaystyle x_{\infty}\) is the eigenvector corresponding to the largest eigenvalue of the matrix in question. In this question the matrix is \(\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}\)

The eigenvalues of \(\displaystyle A-3I\) are the eigenvalues of A shifted by 3. For the inverse matrix, take the inverse of these eigenvalues. Find the eigenvalue of \(\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}\) with the largest absolute value, as well as the corresponding eigenvalue of A.

question: 7 (a)
sols_html:
Using the hints, we know that \(\displaystyle \mathbf{x}_{\infty}\) is the eigenvector associated to the largest eigenvalue of the matrix \(\displaystyle (A - 3I)^{-1}\).

The eigenvalues of \(\displaystyle A-3I\) are the eigenvalues of \(A\) shifted by 3, with the same eigenvectors. We can see this by noting for each eigenvector \(v\) of \(A\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (A-3I)v = Av - 3v = \lambda v - 3v = (\lambda - 3)v\end{aligned}\]

Since \(A\) has the eigenvalues \(\lambda_0 = 0\), \(\lambda_1 = 1\), \(\lambda_2 = 4\) and \(\lambda_3 = 5\), the matrix \(\displaystyle A - 3I\) has the eigenvalues \(\eta_0 = -3\), \(\eta_1 = -2\), \(\eta_3 = 1\) and \(\eta_4 = 2\). Next, the eigenvalues of the inverse \(\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}\) are the reciprocal of the original eigenvalues, with the same eigenvectors. Hence the eigenvalues of \(\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}\) are \(\gamma_0 = -1/3\), \(\gamma_1 = -1/2\), \(\gamma_3 = 1\) and \(\gamma_4 = 1/2\). We see that the dominating eigenvalue of \(\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}\) is \(\gamma_3 = 1\), and therefore, by the power method, \(\mathbf{x}_\infty\) is an eigenvector of \(\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}\) with eigenvalue 1.

This means that \(\mathbf{x}_\infty\) is also an eigenvector of \(A\) with eigenvalue \(\lambda_2 = 4\). In other words,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A\mathbf x_{\infty} = 4 \mathbf x_{\infty} = [2,2,2,2]^{T}\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Suppose that \(A\) is a symmetric \(4 \times 4\) matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1, 4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors \(\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^{4}\) by choosing \(\mathbf{x}_0\) at random, and then settings

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\ \mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|\end{aligned}\]

for \(n = 1, 2, \dots\). You then observe that \(\mathbf{x}\)n converges to

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T\end{aligned}\]

as \(n \to \infty\).

(a) What is \(A\mathbf{x}_\infty\)?
